risks.title: High Technical Resource Requirements for Local AI Models
risks.description: Running advanced local AI models like Qwen2.5-VL requires significant hardware, specifically high VRAM and system RAM. This poses a barrier to entry for many users, as dedicated servers or high-end consumer hardware (like a Mac M-series with 64GB RAM) are needed, which could limit the project's mainstream adoption despite its 'user-friendly' claim.

evidence.quote: The 7B/8B Qwen2.5-VL models require approximately 24GB VRAM and 32GB system RAM. The 32B version would need a Mac M-series with at least 32GB RAM (64GB recommended) and over 60GB of storage. These are significant hardware considerations for local deployment.
User hardware costs for running AI models locally can be a barrier.

mitigation: Optimize models for efficient inference on a wider range of hardware.
Provide clear hardware specifications and guides for cost-effective setups.
Offer an optional cloud-based AI processing service for users without sufficient local hardware.
Partner with OEMs to offer custom-branded hardware optimized for PrivateAI at competitive prices.

risks.title: Security Risks with Plugin Architecture and Execution
risks.description: The initial idea of downloading and compiling Rust source code for plugins locally (high-risk method for Rust plugins) poses severe security vulnerabilities and usability challenges. Malware could be introduced, and compilation could fail, making the system unstable or compromised.

evidence.quote: Initial (High-Risk) Idea for Rust Plugins: Download Rust source code, compile it locally on the user's machine, and then run the resulting binary. The core application would manage these processes. Research documents strongly advise against this due to major security risks and usability hurdles.
The 'initial (high-risk) idea for Rust plugins' (local source compilation) is strongly advised against due to security risks and usability hurdles in research documents.

mitigation: Adopt WebAssembly (WASM) for sandboxed execution of plugins, providing a secure and performant environment.
Distribute pre-compiled and digitally signed binaries for plugins to ensure authenticity and integrity.
Implement OS-level sandboxing or MicroVMs for higher security requirements, especially for untrusted sources.
Develop a robust plugin manifest system that clearly defines requested permissions and data access.

risks.title: Challenges in Mobile Data Collection and Integration
risks.description: Full and continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture, as envisioned for desktops, are highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS and Android devices due to strict OS-level restrictions. This significantly limits the 'second brain' functionality on mobile platforms and could hinder pervasive digital life integration.

evidence.quote: Full, continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture (as envisioned for desktops) are highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS and Android devices due to strict OS-level restrictions on background activity and data access.
Mobile app strategy initially focuses on user-initiated actions and available OS integrations due to restrictions on continuous background monitoring.

mitigation: Focus mobile app development on user-initiated actions (e.g., Share Button integration) and available OS integrations (e.g., calendar events, health data).
Explore notifications capture and foreground app capture for context, with explicit user permission.
Prioritize the desktop experience for the MVP and defer complex mobile integrations to later phases, after deeper market and technical evaluation.
Communicate current mobile capabilities clearly to manage user expectations.

risks.title: Dependence on Open-Source Ecosystem and Rapid AI Landscape Changes
risks.description: PrivateAI relies heavily on the open-source AI ecosystem, which is rapidly evolving. While this offers flexibility, it also means constant effort is required to track, integrate, and optimize new models, potentially diverting resources from core development. There's also a risk that larger tech companies could release similar features, impacting the competitive landscape.

evidence.quote: The system needs a strategy for handling updates to local AI models (LLMs, Vision, STT). This includes managing model downloads, resource allocation, and ensuring compatibility as new and improved open-source models emerge frequently. This was noted as a key question for investors.
Rapidly Evolving AI Landscape & Big Tech Competition: Major tech companies could release similar features. This is a significant concern.

mitigation: Invest in a strong Developer Relations (DevRel) team to monitor the AI space and engage with open-source communities.
Implement a flexible architecture (e.g., LiteLLM proxy) to easily swap out or combine different LLMs.
Focus on features that Big Tech cannot easily replicate due to privacy and local-first constraints.
Prioritize modularity to allow for easy integration of new open-source components and models.

risks.title: Sustainability of Monetization Model for Open-Source, Local-First Software
risks.description: Justifying subscription fees for a local-first, open-source product can be challenging, as users might expect core functionality to be free. While a freemium model is planned, convincing users to pay for 'convenience' features (like managed updates or mobile apps) or optional cloud services might prove difficult against the backdrop of a free, open-source core, potentially impacting revenue targets.

evidence.quote: The open-source core system will be free for personal, non-commercial use, with paid 'convenience' features and services offered for an easier setup and managed updates.
Monetization: Justifying subscriptions for local-first software; funding open-source.

mitigation: Clearly articulate the value proposition of paid 'convenience' features, emphasizing time-savings, enhanced experience, and access to managed services like secure remote access.
Offer a one-time purchase option to address concerns about future price increases or service discontinuation.
Diversify revenue streams beyond subscriptions, including a plugin marketplace commission and professional services.
Actively engage with the open-source community to explain the necessity of commercialization for sustainable development.
